messages: cdd23ac03f92596256b5ebc603df251b (22:57): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, you're right, every browser I tested (Opera, Firefox, Chrome, IE) supports it
cdd23ac03f92596256b5ebc603df251b (22:57): a bit surprising given that Opera ever did anything with it UI-wise, as far as I know
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:12): opera only does soemthing ui-wise with it since a few months ago, because chaals wanted to show that a browser implemented it, iirc
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:14): First it was Netscape 4 that was non-compliant, then it was IE6 that was non-compliant...
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:14): The funny thing is, guess when the standards that the browsers were non-compliant dates from?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:15): has any browser ever been fully compliant to any standard?
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:16): If you can't guess it, I am talking about CSS.
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:17): Particularly levels 1 and 2.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:17): the spec for level 2 still isn't done, last i checked
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:17): I am talking about 2.0, not 2.1.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:17): there's no 2.0
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:17): there's just css2, and different revisions of it
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:18): http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-CSS1-961217
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:19): In the meantime, there is the year long gap between drafts of CSS3.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:19): http://www.w3.org/TR/1998/WD-css2-19980128/ http://www.w3.org/TR/2002/WD-CSS21-20020802/
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:20): those are the drafts on either side of the CSS2 draft you cited
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:20): there's nothing special about the contents of the one you cited
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:20): it's just one step along the way of writing the level 2 spec
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:22): Yea, I know 2.1 isn't done.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:22): the ".1" just means "revision 1"
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (23:22): http://www.opera.com/docs/specs/presto27/css/properties/ ‚Üê Fully compliant? Not yet. (c:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:22): which is kind of a misnomer, since it's been dozens of public revisions and thousands of secret ones
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:23): but that's just the way the w3c does things
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:37): &lt da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6> http://www.opera.com/docs/specs/presto27/css/properties/ ‚Üê Fully compliant? Not yet.
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:38): And that is the ridicolous thing.

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:39): 07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a: Ultimately web developers want stuff in CSS3 and not the non-implemented stuff in CSS2 now, and it's ultimately a choice of development resources.

69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (23:52): Apparently browsers reload an iframe when it is moved in the DOM (maybe for security reasons?) but I don't see anything about that here: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/the-iframe-element.html#the-iframe-element
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (23:52): Is it somewhere else or just not specified?
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (23:53): (or am I just missing it?)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:05): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, Julian was suggesting the rules should be the same as they were for HTTP
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:05): but yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:06): 69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537: not all browsers do; the lack of such a requirement in html is intentional
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:09): 118 comments
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:10): name changes sure are popular
cdd23ac03f92596256b5ebc603df251b (00:11): but why, oh why, is the clueless:cluefull ratio so mindbogglingly high?
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (00:12): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e ‚ã± Oh, ok :(
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:12): I have a theory for that and I suppose it is an actual theory
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:13): i updated the faq with most questions i saw
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:13): The more simple the statement the more people will have something to say about it. And the less likely it is that they make sense.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:13): fundamentally the problem seems to be that people think browser vendors receive specs from on-high and implement them atomically
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:13): E.g. changing the parsing algorithm is something few people will have to say something about, and they will mostly make sense.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:13): which is so far from the truth it's laughable, but it is also a theory that matches perfectly the REC model
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:13): if we did do things that way, versioning would make a lot of sense
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:14): Changing the requirements on alt="" is something a lot of people will have something to say about, and far from all of them make sense.
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (00:14): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e ‚ã± http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parkinson%27s_Law_of_Triviality
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:15): yay :)

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:16): I first noticed it on my blog. The subjects I found most interesting and difficult almost nobody cared about it. The subjects that were trivial would get lots of attention. Completely opposite to how I thought it ought to work.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:18): that's the principle behind bikeshedding
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (00:20): Yeah, I've experienced the same pattern on my blog.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:23): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, yeah; for some reason I never really put them together
